title: Patient Surveillance Algorithms for the Emergency Department
segmentation: Hi, I'm Joni Halpern and this is joint work with David Sontag and doctors at the Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, Larry Nathanson, Stephen Horn, and Steve and Nathan Shapiro were working on patient surveillance algorithms for the emergency Department.
And we want to improve care in the emergency Department and the new standard of care.
The hospitals are moving towards the electronic medical record there potentially very useful for monitoring patients.
They are now being updated in real time.
So any information that the hospital comes to know better, patient gets, gets put in their medical record as they find out about it.
They are potentially useful, but the problem is nobody has time to be watching all of these records for all of the patients all of the time.

So what we're interested in asking is, can we build a model of a patient that's based on the information in the EMR so that we can pose clinical important clinical questions and possibly raise alerts for these patients if necessary.
So an example application we're looking at is.
Condition called sepsis.
It arises from the body severe reaction to infection and research has shown that early goal directed therapy helps, but it has to be recognized early and has to be acted upon early.
So an example question we're interested in querying is is this patient at risk for developing sepsis and should we be raising an alert for this patient?
So we can view the electronic medical record as a generative process.
We have.
We have some patient we can't observe directly, but we observe certain things that are kind of produced by this patient or around this patient.
We have different types of data.

There's free text data like triage notes, medical history, there's numerical data, something that we think is going to be really important moving forward that we haven't looked at yet is time series data, repeated vital signs measured every 30 seconds that are being recorded.
But the real question we want to ask is how do we model this patient?
Yeah, previous work that we've done.

Looked at using just the triage notes and representing them by topic distributions to predict whether a patient was at risk for sepsis or not, but we're interested in if we want to incorporate more data in different types of data.
We really want to address that question of how do we model that UN observed patient?
Um?
So one thing we're looking at, we're thinking about now is using the topics that are learned from the triage notes as a possible representation of what's going on with the patient.
Um?

There's a possible justification for this is that the triage notes are written with the express purpose of explaining to the next care provider how to interpret everything they see in the medical record.
So we think maybe the topics uncovered by some sort of topic modeling on the triage note might be a useful latent space for modeling the patient.
We've noticed that the topics seem to correspond to patient types, broad types of patients.
We have to talk about this more of my poster.
Thank you, thank you.
